@graph.caption: This Vegan Frijoles Charros recipe results in a satisfying and warm bowl of tender smoky beans. Perfect for a cold fall day.

@graph.name: Vegan Frijoles Charros Recipe (Mexican Cowboy Beans) « Dora's Table

itemListElement.name: Vegan Frijoles Charros Recipe (Mexican Cowboy Beans)

@graph.headline: Vegan Frijoles Charros Recipe (Mexican Cowboy Beans)

@graph.name: Dora S.
@graph.description: Dora is the founder, recipe developer, and photographer at Dora's Table and Mi Mero Mole. Born and raised in Mexico and a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America in New York, she adopted a vegan (plant-based) diet to take control of her health.

@graph.name: Vegan Frijoles Charros (Mexican Cowboy Beans)
@graph.description: This recipe is an adaptation of the recipe my dad uses at his restaurant.  Frijoles charros, depending on what part of Mexico you are in, include chorizo, sausage or bacon. I made it vegan!
recipeIngredient: ¼ cup Vegetable stock or water

recipeInstructions.text: The next day, strain them and place in a large pot. Pour enough water into the pot to fill ¾ of the way.
recipeInstructions.name: The next day, strain them and place in a large pot. Pour enough water into the pot to fill ¾ of the way.

recipeInstructions.text: Cut your onion in half. Place ½ the onion, cilantro sprigs, and 3 garlic cloves into the pot with the beans. Reserve the other half of the onion.
recipeInstructions.name: Cut your onion in half. Place ½ the onion, cilantro sprigs, and 3 garlic cloves into the pot with the beans. Reserve the other half of the onion.

recipeInstructions.text: Bring water to a simmer and let beans cook until almost tender, approximately 1 ½ hours.
recipeInstructions.name: Bring water to a simmer and let beans cook until almost tender, approximately 1 ½ hours.

recipeInstructions.text: While the beans are cooking heat a large sauté pan to medium-high heat. Add chorizo and sauté until slightly browned, about 4 minutes. While the chorizo is cooking, dice the other half of the onion.
recipeInstructions.name: While the beans are cooking heat a large sauté pan to medium-high heat. Add chorizo and sauté until slightly browned, about 4 minutes. While the chorizo is cooking, dice the other half of the onion.

recipeInstructions.text: Remove chorizo from pan and set aside. Add ¼ cup of water, diced onion, and serrano peppers to the sauté pan. Sweat onion and chiles until tender and translucent about 4 – 5 minutes. Add tomato and let cook for 7-8 minutes more, or until the tomato has broken down and released all of its juices.
recipeInstructions.name: Remove chorizo from pan and set aside. Add ¼ cup of water, diced onion, and serrano peppers to the sauté pan. Sweat onion and chiles until tender and translucent about 4 – 5 minutes. Add tomato and let cook for 7-8 minutes more, or until the tomato has broken down and released all of its juices.

recipeInstructions.text: Add this mixture, and the chorizo to the pot of beans and let simmer for 20 more minutes or until beans are completely tender. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
recipeInstructions.name: Add this mixture, and the chorizo to the pot of beans and let simmer for 20 more minutes or until beans are completely tender. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

recipeInstructions.text: Before serving, remove the half onion, cilantro sprig, and garlic cloves from the beans. Season with salt and pepper
recipeInstructions.name: Before serving, remove the half onion, cilantro sprig, and garlic cloves from the beans. Season with salt and pepper
